column2: Oppressed by such reflections, Andrey Yefimitch relaxed his efforts and gave up visiting the hospital every day.
column3: Oppressed by such reflections, Andrey Yefimitch relaxed his efforts and gave up visiting the hospital every day.

column2: VI

column2: His life was passed like this.
column3: His life was passed like this.

column2: As a rule he got up at eight o'clock in the morning, dressed, and drank his tea.
column3: As a rule he got up at eight o'clock in the morning, dressed, and drank his tea.

column2: Then he sat down in his study to read, or went to the hospital.
column3: Then he sat down in his study to read, or went to the hospital.

column2: At the hospital the out-patients were sitting in the dark, narrow little corridor waiting to be seen by the doctor.
column3: At the hospital the out patients were sitting in the dark, narrow little corridor waiting to be seen by the doctor.

column2: The nurses and the attendants, tramping with their boots over the brick floors, ran by them; gaunt-looking patients in dressing-gowns passed; dead bodies and vessels full of filth were carried by; the children were crying, and there was a cold draught.
column3: The nurses and the attendants, tramping with their boots over the brick floors, ran by them; gaunt looking patients in dressing gowns passed; dead bodies and vessels full of filth were carried by; the children were crying, and there was a cold draught.

column2: Andrey Yefimitch knew that such surroundings were torture to feverish, consumptive, and impressionable patients; but what could be done?
column3: Andrey Yefimitch knew that such surroundings were torture to feverish, consumptive, and impressionable patients; but what could be done?

column2: In the consulting-room he was met by his assistant, Sergey Sergeyitch--a fat little man with a plump, well-washed shaven face, with soft, smooth manners, wearing a new loosely cut suit, and looking more like a senator than a medical assistant.
column3: In the consulting room he was met by his assistant, Sergey Sergeyitch-a fat little man with a plump, well washed shaven face, with soft, smooth manners, wearing a new loosely cut suit, and looking more like a senator than a medical assistant.

column2: He had an immense practice in the town, wore a white tie, and considered himself more proficient than the doctor, who had no practice.
column3: He had an immense practice in the town, wore a white tie, and considered himself more proficient than the doctor, who had no practice.

column2: In the corner of the consulting-room there stood a large ikon in a shrine with a heavy lamp in front of it, and near it a candle-stand with a white cover on it.
column3: In the corner of the consulting room there stood a large ikon in a shrine with a heavy lamp in front of it, and near it a candle stand with a white cover on it.

column2: On the walls hung portraits of bishops, a view of the Svyatogorsky Monastery, and wreaths of dried cornflowers.
column3: On the walls hung portraits of bishops, a view of the Svyatogorsky Monastery, and wreaths of dried cornflowers.

column2: Sergey Sergeyitch was religious, and liked solemnity and decorum.
column3: Sergey Sergeyitch was religious, and liked solemnity and decorum.

column2: The ikon had been put up at his expense; at his instructions some one of the patients read the hymns of praise in the consulting-room on Sundays, and after the reading Sergey Sergeyitch himself went through the wards with a censer and burned incense.
column3: The ikon had been put up at his expense; at his instructions some one of the patients read the hymns of praise in the consulting room on Sundays, and after the reading Sergey Sergeyitch himself went through the wards with a censer and burned incense.

column2: There were a great many patients, but the time was short, and so the work was confined to the asking of a few brief questions and the administration of some drugs, such as castor-oil or volatile ointment.
column3: There were a great many patients, but the time was short, and so the work was confined to the asking of a few brief questions and the administration of some drugs, such as castor oil or volatile ointment.

column2: Andrey Yefimitch would sit with his cheek resting in his hand, lost in thought and asking questions mechanically.
column3: Andrey Yefimitch would sit with his cheek resting in his hand, lost in thought and asking questions mechanically.

column2: Sergey Sergeyitch sat down too, rubbing his hands, and from time to time putting in his word.
column3: Sergey Sergeyitch sat down too, rubbing his hands, and from time to time putting in his word.

column2: We suffer pain and poverty, he would say, "because we do not pray to the merciful God as we should.
column3: We suffer pain and poverty, he would say, "because we do not pray to the merciful God as we should.

column2: Yes!"

column2: Andrey Yefimitch never performed any operation when he was seeing patients; he had long ago given up doing so, and the sight of blood upset him.
column3: Andrey Yefimitch never performed any operation when he was seeing patients; he had long ago given up doing so, and the sight of blood upset him.

column2: When he had to open a child's mouth in order to look at its throat, and the child cried and tried to defend itself with its little hands, the noise in his ears made his head go round and brought tears to his eyes.
column3: When he had to open a child's mouth in order to look at its throat, and the child cried and tried to defend itself with its little hands, the noise in his ears made his head go round and brought tears to his eyes.

column2: He would make haste to prescribe a drug, and motion to the woman to take the child away.
column3: He would make haste to prescribe a drug, and motion to the woman to take the child away.

column2: He was soon wearied by the timidity of the patients and their incoherence, by the proximity of the pious Sergey Sergeyitch, by the portraits on the walls, and by his own questions which he had asked over and over again for twenty years.
column3: He was soon wearied by the timidity of the patients and their incoherence, by the proximity of the pious Sergey Sergeyitch, by the portraits on the walls, and by his own questions which he had asked over and over again for twenty years.

column2: And he would go away after seeing five or six patients.
column3: And he would go away after seeing five or six patients.

column2: The rest would be seen by his assistant in his absence.
column3: The rest would be seen by his assistant in his absence.

column2: With the agreeable thought that, thank God, he had no private practice now, and that no one would interrupt him, Andrey Yefimitch sat down to the table immediately on reaching home and took up a book.
column3: With the agreeable thought that, thank God, he had no private practice now, and that no one would interrupt him, Andrey Yefimitch sat down to the table immediately on reaching home and took up a book.

column2: He read a great deal and always with enjoyment.

column2: Half his salary went on buying books, and of the six rooms that made up his abode three were heaped up with books and old magazines.
column3: Half his salary went on buying books, and of the six rooms that made up his abode three were heaped up with books and old magazines.

column2: He liked best of all works on history and philosophy; the only medical publication to which he subscribed was _The Doctor_, of which he always read the last pages first.
column3: He liked best of all works on history and philosophy; the only medical publication to which he subscribed was underscore The Doctor underscore, of which he always read the last pages first.

column2: He would always go on reading for several hours without a break and without being weary.
column3: He would always go on reading for several hours without a break and without being weary.

column2: He did not read as rapidly and impulsively as Ivan Dmitritch had done in the past, but slowly and with concentration, often pausing over a passage which he liked or did not find intelligible.
column3: He did not read as rapidly and impulsively as Ivan d mitritch had done in the past, but slowly and with concentration, often pausing over a passage which he liked or did not find intelligible.

column2: Near the books there always stood a decanter of vodka, and a salted cucumber or a pickled apple lay beside it, not on a plate, but on the baize table-cloth. Every half-hour he would pour himself out a glass of vodka and drink it without taking his eyes off the book.
column3: Near the books there always stood a decanter of vodka, and a salted cucumber or a pickled apple lay beside it, not on a plate, but on the baize table cloth. Every half hour he would pour himself out a glass of vodka and drink it without taking his eyes off the book.

column3: Then without looking at it he would feel for the cucumber and bite off a bit.

column3: At three o'clock he would go cautiously to the kitchen door; cough, and say, "Daryushka, what about dinner? . ."

column2: After his dinner--a rather poor and untidily served one--Andrey Yefimitch would walk up and down his rooms with his arms folded, thinking.
column3: After his dinner-a rather poor and untidily served one-Andrey Yefimitch would walk up and down his rooms with his arms folded, thinking.

column2: The clock would strike four, then five, and still he would be walking up and down thinking.
column3: The clock would strike four, then five, and still he would be walking up and down thinking.

column3: Occasionally the kitchen door would creak, and the red and sleepy face of Daryushka would appear.

column3: Andrey Yefimitch, isn't it time for you to have your beer? she would ask anxiously.

column2: Towards the evening the postmaster, Mihail Averyanitch, the only man in town whose society did not bore Andrey Yefimitch, would come in.
column3: Towards the evening the postmaster, Mihail Averyanitch, the only man in town whose society did not bore Andrey Yefimitch, would come in.

column2: Mihail Averyanitch had once been a very rich landowner, and had served in the calvary, but had come to ruin, and was forced by poverty to take a job in the post office late in life.
column3: Mihail Averyanitch had once been a very rich landowner, and had served in the calvary, but had come to ruin, and was forced by poverty to take a job in the post office late in life.

column2: He had a hale and hearty appearance, luxuriant grey whiskers, the manners of a well-bred man, and a loud, pleasant voice.
column3: He had a hale and hearty appearance, luxuriant grey whiskers, the manners of a well bred man, and a loud, pleasant voice.

column2: He was good-natured and emotional, but hot-tempered.
column3: He was good-natured and emotional, but hot tempered.

column2: When anyone in the post office made a protest, expressed disagreement, or even began to argue, Mihail Averyanitch would turn crimson, shake all over, and shout in a voice of thunder, "Hold your tongue!" so that the post office had long enjoyed the reputation of an institution which it was terrible to visit.
column3: When anyone in the post office made a protest, expressed disagreement, or even began to argue, Mihail Averyanitch would turn crimson, shake all over, and shout in a voice of thunder, "Hold your tongue!" so that the post office had long enjoyed the reputation of an institution which it was terrible to visit.

column2: Mihail Averyanitch liked and respected Andrey Yefimitch for his culture and the loftiness of his soul; he treated the other inhabitants of the town superciliously, as though they were his subordinates.
column3: Mihail Averyanitch liked and respected Andrey Yefimitch for his culture and the loftiness of his soul; he treated the other inhabitants of the town superciliously, as though they were his subordinates.

column2: Here I am, he would say, going in to Andrey Yefimitch.

column3: On the contrary, I am delighted, said the doctor.

column3: The friends would sit on the sofa in the study and for some time would smoke in silence.

column3: Daryushka, what about the beer? Andrey Yefimitch would say.

column3: They would drink their first bottle still in silence, the doctor brooding and Mihail Averyanitch with a gay and animated face, like a man who has something very interesting to tell.

column2: The doctor was always the one to begin the conversation.

column2: What a pity, he would say quietly and slowly, not looking his friend in the face (he never looked anyone in the face)--"what a great pity it is that there are no people in our town who are capable of carrying on intelligent and interesting conversation, or care to do so.
column3: What a pity, he would say quietly and slowly, not looking his friend in the face (he never looked anyone in the face)--"what a great pity it is that there are no people in our town who are capable of carrying on intelligent and interesting conversation, or care to do so.

column3: Even the educated class do not rise above vulgarity; the level of their development, I assure you, is not a bit higher than that of the lower orders."

column2: You know, of course, the doctor went on quietly and deliberately, "that everything in this world is insignificant and uninteresting except the higher spiritual manifestations of the human mind. Intellect draws a sharp line between the animals and man, suggests the divinity of the latter, and to some extent even takes the place of the immortality which does not exist.
column3: You know, of course, the doctor went on quietly and deliberately, "that everything in this world is insignificant and uninteresting except the higher spiritual manifestations of the human mind. Intellect draws a sharp line between the animals and man, suggests the divinity of the latter, and to some extent even takes the place of the immortality which does not exist.

column2: Consequently the intellect is the only possible source of enjoyment.

column3: We have books, it is true, but that is not at all the same as living talk and converse.

column2: If you will allow me to make a not quite apt comparison: books are the printed score, while talk is the singing."
column3: If you will allow me to make a not quite apt comparison: books are the printed score, while talk is the singing."

column3: Daryushka would come out of the kitchen and with an expression of blank dejection would stand in the doorway to listen, with her face propped on her fist.

column2: I often dream of intellectual people and conversation with them, he said suddenly, interrupting Mihail Averyanitch.

column2: Of course, intellect, too, is transient and not eternal, but you know why I cherish a partiality for it.
column3: Of course, intellect, too, is transient and not eternal, but you know why I cherish a partiality for it.

column2: Life is a vexatious trap; when a thinking man reaches maturity and attains to full consciousness he cannot help feeling that he is in a trap from which there is no escape.
column3: Life is a vexatious trap; when a thinking man reaches maturity and attains to full consciousness he cannot help feeling that he is in a trap from which there is no escape.

column2: Indeed, he is summoned without his choice by fortuitous circumstances from non-existence into life . . . what for?
column3: Indeed, he is summoned without his choice by fortuitous circumstances from non existence into life . . . what for?

column2: He tries to find out the meaning and object of his existence; he is told nothing, or he is told absurdities; he knocks and it is not opened to him; death comes to him--also without his choice.
column3: He tries to find out the meaning and object of his existence; he is told nothing, or he is told absurdities; he knocks and it is not opened to him; death comes to him-also without his choice.

column2: And so, just as in prison men held together by common misfortune feel more at ease when they are together, so one does not notice the trap in life when people with a bent for analysis and generalization meet together and pass their time in the interchange of proud and free ideas.
column3: And so, just as in prison men held together by common misfortune feel more at ease when they are together, so one does not notice the trap in life when people with a bent for analysis and generalization meet together and pass their time in the interchange of proud and free ideas.

column2: In that sense the intellect is the source of an enjoyment nothing can replace."

column2: Oh, why is not man immortal?

column2: What is the good of the brain centres and convolutions, what is the good of sight, speech, self-consciousness, genius, if it is all destined to depart into the soil, and in the end to grow cold together with the earth's crust, and then for millions of years to fly with the earth round the sun with no meaning and no object?
column3: What is the good of the brain centres and convolutions, what is the good of sight, speech, self consciousness, genius, if it is all destined to depart into the soil, and in the end to grow cold together with the earth's crust, and then for millions of years to fly with the earth round the sun with no meaning and no object?

column2: To do that there was no need at all to draw man with his lofty, almost godlike intellect out of non-existence, and then, as though in mockery, to turn him into clay.

column2: The transmutation of substances!

column2: But what cowardice to comfort oneself with that cheap substitute for immortality!
column3: But what cowardice to comfort oneself with that cheap substitute for immortality!

column2: The unconscious processes that take place in nature are lower even than the stupidity of man, since in stupidity there is, anyway, consciousness and will, while in those processes there is absolutely nothing.
column3: The unconscious processes that take place in nature are lower even than the stupidity of man, since in stupidity there is, anyway, consciousness and will, while in those processes there is absolutely nothing.
